awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Rare Earth Element Extraction from End-of-Life Fluorescent Light Bulb Powder
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to enable new technologies, such as additive manufacturing and electronics, that require special natural materials known as Rare Earth Elements (REE). Current REE extraction methods produce large quantities of toxic materials requiring mitigation. The proposed solution advances an extraction method that is environmentally friendly and generates no toxic byproducts, can be used with broad material sources (including recycled goods), uses less energy, and is readily scalable to deliver at a significantly lower cost.  

This SBIR Phase I project proposes a reactor system that incorporates precision ultra-high temperature heating to evaporate targeted material constituents and subsequently condense to separate REEs.  The approach optimizes thermal energy to efficiently achieve tailorable temperatures for the extraction and separation of REEs from a broad range of source material, including recycled Fluorescent Light Bulb (FLB) powder that contains significant concentrations of Yttrium, Europium and Terbium. This project will engineer a fully integrated prototype system that ingests waste FLB powder, extracts the REE constituents via precision heating, and then separates them in high purity via controlled evaporation and condensation.  Research tasks include development of a reliable calibration procedure that simultaneously sets reactor current, voltage, and temperature for optimal evaporation.  The end goal is to demonstrate commercial viability that yields an alternative REE extraction and separation approach that is economically and environmentally superior to existing chemical-based processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Rare Earth Elements (REEs), 16 of them existing in nature, are among the set of critical materials defined by the US Government. These elements are a key makeup of modern technology, playing an important component role in many consumer products like cell phones, computer memories, TV screens, fluorescent bulbs, hybrid and electric cars, lasers, medical systems and more. Rare Earth Elements are also an integral part in a wide range of technologies relevant to national defense, including avionics, sonar, night vision, GPS, stealth technology, missile guidance systems, and more.

The US has lost its leading role in mining and producing REEs decades ago to China.  As the leading producer of REEs and derivative products with over 80% market share, China poses significant influence over a world market representing greater than $7 Trillion of global GDP in end products. The primary reason for such dependence on China is the unacceptable toxic burden common chemical REE extraction methods put on the environment. IM Technologies (IMT) has developed an environmentally friendly, energy efficient approach that can enable REE extraction, leveraging a novel high temperature reactor system.  The process can accommodate a broad range of feedstock, from mined raw material to waste or recycled products.  This high temperature reactor technology is ideally suited for helping reestablish the domestic REE supply chain.

During the NSF Phase I project, IM Technologies focused in applying the high temperature reactor system technology on End-of-Life Fluorescent Light Bulb (FLB) powder as a primary source material for processing. Recycling of FLBs involves the removal of mercury content prior to landfill disposal to avoid contamination by the toxic chemical.  If leaked into the Earth, mercury can find its way into groundwater, resulting in negative health reactions among humans. The phosphor waste material that is produced during the mercury distillation process contains five rare earth elements: Yttrium, Lanthanum, Cerium, Europium and Terbium. All five REEs have significant importance in a wide range of commercial and military applications.  Approximately 300 g of rare-earth compounds can be recovered from 1 kg of phosphor waste, analogous to the processing of 12 to 23 kg (50 lbs.) site-specific primary ore.

Source material from a US based recycling company that has accumulated over 10 million pounds of FLB powder was used to demonstrate feasibility of the high temperature reactor approach.   Initial studies were carried out by leveraging a traditionally constructed furnace setup to generate a set of metrics on gross operating conditions. These initial studies also provided various levels of validity on process implementation for FLB powder to REE concentrate reduction, as well as REE oxide to metal conversion. Significant effort was spent on understanding experimental conditions for optimal REE extraction, so that a GEN1 furnace design can be formulated. The GEN1 furnace design was also driven by requirements for improved logistical viability that can be matured further to support scale-up and increased throughput.

Extraction of rare earth metals from end-of-life fluorescent light bulb powder was demonstrated successfully during the NSF SBIR Phase I effort. The relatively simple process resulted into a reduced mixture of materials, called mischmetal, a REE concentrate that contained a prevailing presence of Yttrium, given that Yttrium is a major component of FLB powder. Measurements were performed leveraging Scanning Electron Microscopy and X-ray diffractometer particle characterization tools at the Brookhaven National Laboratory Center of Functional Nanomaterials. Together with operational testing carried out with the GEN1 furnace setup, the collective results obtained over the course of the effort provide a good foundation basis from which a next level effort can lead to an integrated logistically viable prototype system for REE metal production.

In addition, reduction of several oxides to pure metals was investigated and successfully carried out for primarily Yttrium, but also for Lanthanum, Cerium and Neodymium.  Much of early stage production yields REEs in oxide, carbide, chloride or fluoride form.  Conversion to pure metal is of significance as it results in a significantly higher valued commodity product.

A patent expanding on the broad applicability of the high temperature reactor system technology was granted during the SBIR Phase I period of performance (US11,389,874).  The patent was filed prior to the NSF award, and with its issuance, brings the total number of granted patents related to the high temperature reactor technology to five.
